questions.text: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and acute right lower abdominal pain. On examination, he was febrile and his pulse rate was 106 beats/min. Tenderness was felt in right iliac fossa. The CT scan image is shown below. Which of the following signs will not be seen in this disease? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ballance sign

 

The patient's history and CT findings are indicative of acute appendicitis. Ballance sign is not seen in acute appendicitis.

 

Ballance's sign is seen in splenic trauma, where dullness is seen on right flank on percussion, which doesn’t shift on lateral position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McBurney's tenderness: Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus.

 

Option B. Rovsing sign: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa causes pain in the right iliac fossa.

 

Option C. Psoas sign: Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Sometimes, the inflamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip flexed, for pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Findings on CT that are suggestive of acute appendicitis include:

 

  • Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm in diameter)
  • Appendiceal wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency with a BP of 160/100 mg and a heart rate of 120 bpm. CECT done reveals a Stanford type A aortic dissection. What is the initial management of this given condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta blocker medication

 

Beta-blockers are used to control the heart rate and blood pressure in patients with aortic dissection. This helps in reducing the sheer force exerted on the wall of the aorta, which may help in preventing the progression of the dissection. Beta-blockers are the first-line medication for heart rate and blood pressure control in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin): This is an anticoagulant used to prevent or treat blood clots. In the context of an aortic dissection, it's not the initial management as it might increase the risk of bleeding within the dissection.

 

Option C. Surgical repair: Emergency surgical correction is the preferred treatment for Stanford type A (DeBakey type I and II) ascending aortic dissection. However, before surgery, it is crucial to stabilize the patient's vital signs, and beta-blockers play a significant role in this aspect.

 

Option D. Vitamin K inhibitors: These are anticoagulants that act by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Like LMWH, they are not the initial management for aortic dissection due to the potential risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection is Beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The Preferred Beta-blocker drug is Esmolol.

 

Once hypertension is controlled, then definitive repair of aortic dissection is done based on Stanford type.

 

Stanford Classification:

 

  • Type A: This type involves the ascending aorta and possibly the descending aorta. It is considered the more dangerous type and often requires emergency surgery. Given its involvement with the ascending aorta, it's critical to manage promptly to avoid complications such as rupture or impairment of blood flow to vital organs.
  • Type B: Involves only the descending aorta.

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Severe, sudden, tearing chest pain
  • Pain that radiates to the back/scapula
  • Shortness of breath
  • Sweating
  • Weakness or paralysis on one side of the body (in rare cases)

 

Treatment:

 

  • Medical Management: Medications, especially beta-blockers, are often given initially to lower heart rate and blood pressure, reducing the force of blood against the aortic walls and potentially preventing further tearing.
  • Surgical Intervention: Emergency surgical correction is the preferred treatment for Stanford type A dissections. The surgery aims to repair the damaged section of the aorta and to prevent rupture or further dissection. Endovascular repair is preferred for Stanford B.

questions.text: How is wound infection severity graded? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southampton grading

 

Southampton wound grading system is a scoring system for the severity of wound infection.

 

  • The Southampton Wound Grading System is a widely recognized method for grading wound infection severity.
  • It categorizes surgical site infections (SSI) into different grades based on clinical signs, such as erythema (redness), purulent discharge, and wound breakdown.
  • The grading system allows healthcare providers to classify SSIs as minor, moderate, or severe based on specific criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASA classification: The ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification system is primarily used to assess a patient's overall health and fitness for surgery.

 

  • It does not directly grade wound infection severity.

 

Option B. SIRS criteria (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome): SIRS criteria are used to identify systemic inflammation and are not specific to grading wound infection severity.

 

  • These criteria include parameters like temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and white blood cell count.

 

Option D. APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II): The APACHE II score is a severity of illness scoring system used to assess critically ill patients in intensive care units.

 

  • It does not directly relate to grading wound infection severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Southampton grading:

 

 

In summary, the Southampton grading system is the appropriate option for grading wound infection severity as it provides a structured approach to categorizing surgical site infections based on clinical criteria. This system helps healthcare providers assess the seriousness of wound infections and make appropriate treatment decisions.

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

 

Inadequate preparation of a patient with hyperthyroidism before thyroidectomy, such as not optimizing thyroid function and medication management, can increase the risk of thyroid storm. Proper preoperative management and stabilization of thyroid function are crucial to prevent this complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rough handling of thyroid during surgery: While rough handling during thyroid surgery can potentially lead to complications, it is not the usual cause of thyroid storm.

 

Option B. Due to parathyroid gland injury: The parathyroid glands are separate from the thyroid gland and regulate calcium levels in the body. Complications involving the parathyroid glands can occur during thyroid surgery leading to postoperative hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Infections: Infections can occur as complications after thyroid surgery, but they are not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is primarily related to the excessive release of thyroid hormones into the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.

 

Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:

 

  1. High fever
  2. Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  3. Elevated blood pressure
  4. Extreme agitation and restlessness
  5. Profuse sweating
  6. Tremors and shaking
  7. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  8. Delirium or confusion
  9. Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  10. Coma (in severe cases)

 

Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.

 

The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

questions.text: Heller's operation is performed for: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

 

The most common surgical procedure done for achalasia cardia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy in conjugation with partial fundoplication.

 

Heller's operation is most commonly performed to treat Achalasia cardia. Achalasia is a medical condition characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax properly, leading to difficulty in swallowing and the accumulation of food in the esophagus. Heller myotomy involves cutting the muscles of the LES to alleviate the obstruction and improve the passage of food into the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Cancer of the esophagus is typically treated with other approaches such as surgery to remove the tumor, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination of these treatments.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: Esophageal stricture refers to the narrowing of the esophagus, often due to scar tissue formation. Treatment for esophageal strictures may involve dilation procedures or other surgical techniques depending on the underlying cause.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Treatment for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically involves a surgical procedure called Ramsteads pyloromyotomy to alleviate the obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia, commonly referred to as achalasia, is a medical condition that affects the esophagus, specifically the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and the muscles of the esophageal wall. This condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  1. Failure of LES Relaxation: In achalasia, the LES, a muscular ring that separates the esophagus from the stomach, does not relax properly during swallowing. Normally, the LES should relax to allow food and liquids to pass into the stomach, but in achalasia, this relaxation is impaired.
  2. Incomplete Emptying of the Esophagus: Due to the dysfunctional LES, the esophagus is unable to empty food and liquids into the stomach efficiently. This leads to a gradual buildup of food and fluids in the esophagus, causing symptoms.
  3. Difficulty in Swallowing: The most prominent symptom of achalasia is dysphagia, which is difficulty in swallowing. Patients often experience a sensation of food getting stuck in the chest while eating and may need to drink fluids or change their body position to help food pass into the stomach.
  4. Regurgitation: As a result of the esophageal emptying problems, patients with achalasia may also experience regurgitation of undigested food, often occurring at night when lying down.
  5. Chest Pain: Some individuals with achalasia may experience chest pain or discomfort, often due to the accumulation of food and fluids in the esophagus.

 

Achalasia is typically diagnosed through tests such as esophageal manometry, which measures the pressure within the esophagus, and barium swallow studies, which show the narrowing of the esophagus and the delayed emptying of contrast material.

 

Treatment options for achalasia include:

 

  • Heller Myotomy: This surgical procedure involves cutting the muscles of the LES to allow for improved passage of food and liquids into the stomach. It is the primary surgical treatment for achalasia.
  • Pneumatic Dilation: In this non-surgical procedure, a balloon is inflated within the LES to stretch and disrupt the muscle fibers, making it easier for food to pass.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection: Injecting botulinum toxin directly into the LES can help relax the muscle temporarily. However, this treatment may need to be repeated periodically.

 

The choice of treatment depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the severity of the condition. Effective management of achalasia can alleviate symptoms and improve the quality of life for individuals with this disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department with a pulsatile mass in the inguinal region. Imaging studies reveal a pseudoaneurysm involving an artery. What is the most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral artery

 

The femoral artery is a common site for pseudoaneurysm formation, especially in individuals with a history of intravenous drug use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: While pseudoaneurysms can occur in the aorta, they are less common than in peripheral arteries like the femoral artery.

 

Option C. Popliteal artery: Pseudoaneurysms can occur in the popliteal artery, but they are less common than in the femoral artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A pseudoaneurysm is a pulsatile hematoma that forms when there is a breach in the arterial wall, resulting in the extravasation of blood into the surrounding tissues.
  • The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation is the femoral artery, due to its superficial location and frequent use for arterial access.
  • Pseudoaneurysms can also occur in other arteries, such as the brachial, radial, ulnar, and carotid arteries.
  • Common causes of pseudoaneurysm formation include trauma, iatrogenic injury during medical procedures (e.g., arterial catheterization), and underlying arterial disease (e.g., atherosclerosis).
  • The clinical presentation of a pseudoaneurysm may include a pulsatile mass, pain, tenderness, and signs of bleeding or hematoma formation.
  • The diagnosis of a pseudoaneurysm is confirmed by imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT scan, or angiography.
  • Treatment options for a pseudoaneurysm may include observation, compression, percutaneous thrombin injection, or surgical repair depending on the size, location, and underlying cause of the lesion.
  • MC site of true peripheral aneurysm is however, the popliteal artery.

questions.text: The procedure in the image shows methylene blue dye being injected in the peritumoral region. What is this procedure used for? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

 

The utility of injection of methylene blue in the region around the tumor is for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB).

 

  • Methylene blue dye, along with other tracers, is commonly employed in sentinel lymph node biopsy procedures. Sentinel lymph nodes are the first lymph nodes that cancer is likely to spread to from a primary tumor. By injecting the dye around the tumor, these sentinel lymph nodes can be identified and biopsied to determine if cancer has spread to them. This helps in staging and planning further treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLN biopsy rationale:

 

Afferent lymphatics from a primary tumor first drain into the sentinel node, before draining into the other nodes.

 

So, if sentinel lymph node is positive, it is possible that the other axillary nodes are also involved. Hence, axillary dissection would be necessary.

 

If the sentinel node is tumor free, then regional nodal metastasis is unlikely.

 

The nodes can be identified using:

 

  • Fluorescein dye
  • Methylene blue
  • Radioactive sulfur colloid-labeled albumin

 

The recommended site of injection is in the subdermal plexus surrounding the nipple.

 

This is used in patients with clinically node-negative disease.

questions.text: The best way to manage the wound shown in the image is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cleaning and dressing

 

The image shows an abrasion. Since it is going to heal with primary intention, no grafting is required.

 

  • Cleaning the wound involves gently removing any debris, foreign material, or contaminants from the wound site. This step helps prevent infection and promotes a healthy healing environment.
  • Dressing the wound involves covering it with a sterile bandage or dressing. Dressings help maintain a moist environment, protect the wound from further contamination, and provide a barrier against external factors.

 

In many cases, initial wound management involves cleaning the wound to prevent infection and applying a sterile dressing. This basic approach is suitable for wounds that are not deeply contaminated, do not require extensive tissue removal (debridement), and do not necessitate advanced interventions like grafting (skin graft or allograft). It provides a clean and protected environment for natural healing to occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Debridement and dressing: Debridement involves the removal of dead or contaminated tissue from the wound, which may be necessary in cases of severe infection or tissue damage. After debridement, the wound is dressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here are some general principles for the management of a superficial abrasion:

 

  1. Clean the wound: Gently clean the wound with soap and warm water to remove any dirt or debris. Use a clean cloth or sterile gauze to pat the wound dry.
  2. Apply a dressing: Cover the abrasion with a sterile dressing or adhesive bandage to keep it clean and protected. Change the dressing daily or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
  3. Manage pain: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  4. Watch for signs of infection: Keep an eye on the abrasion for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pus, or increasing pain.
  5. Follow up: Depending on the severity of the abrasion, you may need to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.

questions.text: Identify which of these is not a component of qSOFA? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral absent pupillary reflex

 

qSOFA stands for Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment. It is a simplified bedside clinical tool used to quickly assess the risk of organ failure and sepsis in patients. qSOFA includes three Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Respiratory Rate ≥ 22/min: A respiratory rate of 22 or higher per minute suggests abnormal breathing and is one of the criteria in qSOFA.
  2. Altered Mental Status: Altered mental status, such as confusion or disorientation, is also a component of qSOFA. It reflects the patient's neurological status and helps in evaluating the severity of illness.
  3. Systolic Blood Pressure < 100 mm Hg: A systolic blood pressure (BP) less than 100 mm Hg indicates poor perfusion and is another parameter in qSOFA.

 

Derangement in 2 or 3 components carries high mortality.

 

Option D: Bilateral absent pupillary reflex: Not a component of qSOFA. The qSOFA score does not include any criteria related to pupillary reflexes. Bilateral absent pupillary reflex is more relevant to assessing brainstem function or neurological assessment rather than organ failure related to sepsis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

qSOFA includes three criteria for assessing sepsis risk: respiratory rate ≥ 22/min, systolic BP < 100 mm Hg, and altered mental status. It does not include pupillary reflex assessment.

questions.text: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute Pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis

 

  • ERCP is not the best diagnostic option for acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis.

 

ERCP is typically not the first-line diagnostic tool for acute pancreatitis unless there is a specific reason to suspect bile duct involvement or gallstones as a cause. It is not routinely used for diagnosing acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent pancreatitis: ERCP can be useful in diagnosing the cause of recurrent pancreatitis, especially if there is a suspicion of gallstones or other biliary problems contributing to the condition like pancreas divisum.

 

Option B. Unexplained jaundice: ERCP is valuable in cases of unexplained jaundice because it can help identify any blockages or abnormalities in the bile ducts or pancreatic ducts that may be causing the jaundice.

 

Option C. Periampullary mass: ERCP can aid in the evaluation of periampullary masses, as it allows visualization and potential tissue sampling from this region, helping in Diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography, which is used to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree using a side-viewing endoscope.
  • ERCP can be therapeutic or diagnostic and is the best modality for examining the distal biliary tree.
  • Indications for ERCP include relieving biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease, biliary drainage, biliary stenting for strictures and leakage, tissue sampling of the biliary or pancreatic ductal system, balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures, sphincterotomy, and sphincter of Oddi manometry.
  • Therapeutic ERCP is most commonly used to alleviate biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.
  • ERCP can be used to diagnose pancreatic divisum, which may present with recurrent pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child is found to have a unilateral undescended testis on the right side during a routine physical exam. A diagnostic laparoscopy is performed, which reveals blind-ending testicular vessels and vas deferens on the right side. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nothing to be done

 

Blind-ending vas deferens and testicular vessels imply anorchism or testicular agenesis. In such cases, no further exploration is required.

 

When diagnostic laparoscopy reveals blind-ending testicular vessels, it indicates the absence or nonviable nature of the testis. In such cases, there is no surgical intervention required because there is no viable testis to locate or bring down. The appropriate management approach is to monitor the patient and provide counseling regarding the absence of the testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inguinal exploration: Inguinal exploration involves surgical exploration of the inguinal canal to locate and bring down an undescended testis. However, in this case, the diagnostic laparoscopy has already revealed blind-ending testicular vessels on the right side. This finding indicates that the testis is absent or nonviable, and no further surgical exploration is needed.

 

Option B. Abdominal exploration: Abdominal exploration is typically performed when an undescended testis is suspected to be located within the abdominal cavity. However, in this case, the laparoscopy has confirmed the absence of a viable testis on the right side.

 

Option C. Scrotal exploration: Scrotal exploration involves surgical exploration of the scrotum to locate and bring down an undescended testis. However, in this case, the laparoscopy findings have already established the absence of a viable testis on the right side, making scrotal exploration unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A unilateral undescended testis refers to a condition in which only one of the testes has not descended into the scrotum, while the other testis has descended normally. This condition is relatively common in male infants and can occur on either the right or left side.

 

Here are some key points about unilateral undescended testis:

 

  1. Incidence: It is one of the most common congenital anomalies in male infants, with the majority of cases involving the left testis.
  2. Diagnosis: Unilateral undescended testis is typically diagnosed during a physical examination, such as a routine well-baby check or pediatric evaluation.
  3. Management: The management of unilateral undescended testis may vary based on the age of the child and the specific circumstances. In many cases, the testis will descend into the scrotum on its own within the first few months of life. If the testis has not descended by the age of 6 months, treatment options may include hormone therapy to stimulate descent or surgical intervention (orchidopexy) to bring the testis down into the scrotum.
  4. Importance of Treatment: The goal of treatment is to ensure that the undescended testis is properly positioned in the scrotum. This is important for several reasons, including the potential impact on fertility and the increased risk of testicular cancer in undescended testes if left untreated.

questions.text: You are the on-call surgeon who is called for an emergency laparotomy for a patient with suspected bowel obstruction. During the surgery, which organ will you first visualize to determine if the obstruction is in the small or large bowel? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caecum

 

  • The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.
  • Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.
  • Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: A trauma patient suffered a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He was managed conservatively. However, after a few days, he presented with a urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureteral stenting

 

The patient in the given question has renal laceration with urine extravasation, which classifies as grade 4 renal injury.

 

Ureteral stenting is a minimally invasive procedure that can help alleviate the obstruction and promote urine drainage, reducing the risk of infection and other complications associated with urinomas

 

Ureteral stenting involves the placement of a stent into the ureter to facilitate drainage of urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder. In the context of a urinoma, this can help alleviate the obstruction or urine accumulation, providing relief and preventing further complications. It is similar to placement of CBD stent via ERCP in cystic duct leak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical Repair and Exploration: Surgical repair and exploration may be considered if there is a significant structural or anatomical issue contributing to the urinoma that cannot be resolved through less invasive methods.

 

Option C. Observation: Observation alone may not be sufficient if the urinoma is causing discomfort, pain, or complications. It's crucial to address the urinoma promptly.

 

Option D. Percutaneous Drainage: Percutaneous drainage may be an option, but ureteral stenting is a more specific approach for managing urinomas resulting from ureteral obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A urinoma is a collection of urine that has leaked from the urinary tract and has accumulated outside its normal anatomical location. This condition typically occurs due to trauma, injury, or obstruction in the urinary system.

 

  1. Causes: Urinomas are usually caused by trauma, such as blunt abdominal or pelvic trauma, that leads to injury to the urinary collecting system. They can also result from urinary tract obstruction, infections, or surgical complications.
  2. Symptoms: Common symptoms of a urinoma may include abdominal or flank pain, fever, and swelling in the affected area. In some cases, urinomas may be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during imaging studies.
  3. Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a combination of medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies, such as ultrasound, CT scans, or MRI, to visualize the urinoma and determine its size and location.

 

A persistent urinoma (a mass formed by encapsulated extravasated urine) should be managed with the placement of an internal ureteral stent.

 

Patients not cured by ureteral stenting may require percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drainage.

choices.text: A, B, C and D

questions.text: Which of the following are used to stop esophageal variceal bleed? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and C

 

 A, B, C can be used to stop esophageal variceal bleed.

 

 A: Sengstaken Blakemore tube

 

 B: Minnesota tube

 

 C: Gastric endoscope

 

A. Sengstaken Blakemore Tube:

 

  • The Sengstaken Blakemore tube is a medical device used for emergency management of esophageal and gastric variceal bleeding by causing balloon tamponade effect, typically associated with liver cirrhosis.
  • It consists of three lumens: one for inflation of esophageal and gastric balloons each and one for aspiration of gastric contents

 

B. Minnesota Tube:

 

  • Similar to SB tube, this has 4 channels, additionally for esophageal aspiration. It is also used for balloon tamponade.

 

C. Gastric Endoscope:

 

  • A gastric endoscope, also known as a gastroscopy or upper endoscopy, is a flexible tube with a camera at the end used for examining the esophagus, stomach, and the beginning of the small intestine.
  • It is primarily a diagnostic tool which can also be used for therapeutic interventions like variceal banding or sclerotherapy.

 

Other option:

 

D. Fiberoptic Bronchoscope:

 

  • A fiberoptic bronchoscope is a medical instrument used for examining the airways and lungs. It consists of a flexible tube with a light source and a camera that is passed through the nose or mouth into the trachea and bronchi.
  • It is used for diagnostic and therapeutic procedures related to the respiratory system, such as visualizing and obtaining samples from the airways, removing foreign bodies, and managing airway issues.

questions.text: Size cut off for operating an abdominal aortic aneurysm is greater than? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5.5 cm

 

(5.5) The threshold for surgical repair of an AAA is commonly set at 5.5 cm in diameter. This means that when the AAA reaches or exceeds 5.5 cm in size, surgical intervention is usually recommended to prevent the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AAA refers to an enlargement or ballooning of the abdominal aorta. It can be a potentially life-threatening condition if it ruptures.

 

The size of the AAA is a crucial factor in determining the need for surgical intervention. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the size of the aneurysm grows.

 

An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient is considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter (measured by ultrasonography). The annual incidence of rupture rises from 1% or less in aneurysms that are <55 mm in diameter to a significant level of nearly 25%, in those that are 70 mm in diameter.

 

As open elective surgery (transabdominal) carries a 5% mortality rate, the balance is in favor of elective operation once the maximum diameter is >55 mm.

 

6 monthly follow-up ultrasonographic surveillance is indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms <55 mm in diameter.

choices.text: Strap his thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
Roll the patient and put on a hard board

questions.text: All of the following are done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately

 

This option is not a standard practice when transporting conscious polytrauma patients. Shifting a conscious patient to a lateral position and immediately moving them can risk further injury and discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strap his thorax, abdomen, and lower limbs on a stretcher: This is a common and necessary practice when transporting a conscious polytrauma patient. It helps secure the patient to the stretcher to prevent movement and further injury during transport.

 

Option B. Apply a cervical collar: This is done to immobilize the cervical spine, till a cervical injury is ruled out.

 

Option D. Roll the patient and put on a hardboard: Rolling a conscious polytrauma patient and placing them on a hardboard (spinal board) can be a part of the standard protocol for immobilizing the spine and minimizing movement during transport. This is done to prevent potential spinal cord injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with polytrauma are shifted in supine or prone position (not in lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface, in order to restrict the spinal movement.

 

As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients unless proven otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column.

 

The patient is placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar (Philadelphia collar) is applied.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial thickness burn? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary dermis

 

The papillary dermis is a layer of the skin that lies just below the epidermis. Blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns occurs within this layer, as it is the point where the burn has affected both the epidermis and the upper portion of the dermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermis: The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin. In superficial partial thickness burns, this layer is typically damaged, but blister formation occurs slightly deeper within the skin.

 

Option B. Subcutaneous tissue: The subcutaneous tissue is located beneath the dermis and is not typically involved in blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns.

 

Option D. Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis is located deeper in the skin and is not primarily associated with blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns. Blister formation occurs closer to the surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The papillary dermis is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial-thickness burn.

 

First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, with pain, redness, and mild swelling.

 

Second-degree burns involve the epidermis and some parts of the dermis (also known as partial-thickness burns). Further classified as-

 

  • Superficial second degree or superficial partial-thickness burn - involves the upper part of the dermis (papillary) and shows pain, blisters, and severe swelling.
  • Deep second degree or deep partial-thickness burn - extends deeper up to the reticular layer of the dermis and appears paler and more mottled, does not blanch to touch, but remains painful to pinprick.

 

Third-degree or full-thickness burns involve the complete thickness of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

choices.text: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman came with a history of thyroid swelling. FNAC was done and the report was suggestive of papillary carcinoma thyroid. The nodule was "cold" on scan. Which of the following will not be a treatment option for her? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radioiodine ablation of thyroid

 

Radioiodine ablation is typically used after thyroidectomy to eliminate any remaining thyroid tissue and residual cancer cells. However, it is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of harm to the developing fetus from radiation exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Thyroidectomy: This option involves the complete removal of the thyroid gland and is a standard treatment for papillary thyroid carcinoma. However, the timing of the surgery during pregnancy should be carefully considered in consultation with an experienced healthcare team.

 

Option B. Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph Node Dissection: In cases where there is evidence of lymph node involvement or a high risk of lymph node metastasis, total thyroidectomy with lymph node dissection may be recommended to remove affected lymph nodes in the neck. Again, the timing and extent of surgery should be carefully evaluated during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Right Hemithyroidectomy: Right hemithyroidectomy involves the removal of one lobe (half) of the thyroid gland. This procedure is considered when there is a single, localized thyroid nodule or cancer confined to one side of the thyroid gland. However, for papillary carcinoma thyroid, total thyroidectomy is often preferred to ensure complete removal of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiation exposure to the fetus.

 

Therapeutic uses for Radioactive lodine

 

  1. In primary thyrotoxicosis after the age of 45 years.
  2. In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland will still function adequately after radiotherapy.
  3. In papillary/follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I 131 is given.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Renal calculus of > 4 cm of the Staghorn type. What is the best management modality in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

 

PCNL is the preferred treatment for large and complex kidney stones, especially Staghorn calculi. It involves making a small incision in the patient's back to access the kidney directly. A nephroscope is then used to remove or break up the stone. PCNL is highly effective in managing large stones like Staghorn calculi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller pieces, making them easier to pass. While ESWL is effective for smaller kidney stones (<2cm), it may not be as successful for very large and complex Staghorn calculi.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to reach the stone in the kidney or upper urinary tract. While it can be effective for ureteric stones, it may not be the best choice for Staghorn calculi, especially those larger than 4 cm.

 

Option D. Open pyelolithotomy: This may be done in cases where PCNL fails or is contra-indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the gold standard for the management of large and complex stones, like in this case.

 

PCNL is indicated in

 

  • Staghorn calculi - Stone >2 cm
  • Multiple stones - >1 cm

 

ESWL is only 45-60% efficacious in the treatment of large stones. Also, it causes frequent complications including pain, hydronephrosis, fever, and occasional urosepsis, due to difficulties in the passage of stone particles, especially when there has been insufficient disintegration.

 

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:

 

  • Hemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma
  • Perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant
  • Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.text: A 46-year-old female is undergoing thyroidectomy for a large goiter. During the procedure, the patient develops tachycardia, hypertension, and hyperthermia. She becomes agitated and confused. Laboratory tests reveal elevated thyroid hormone levels, and a diagnosis of thyroid storm is made. The surgical team immediately stops the procedure, and the patient is transferred to the intensive care unit for treatment. What is the most common cause of thyroid storm during thyroidectomy? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

 

Inadequate preparation of a patient with hyperthyroidism before thyroidectomy, such as not optimizing thyroid function and medication management, can increase the risk of thyroid storm. Proper preoperative management and stabilization of thyroid function are crucial to prevent this complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rough handling of thyroid during surgery: While rough handling during thyroid surgery can potentially lead to complications, it is not the usual cause of thyroid storm.

 

Option B. Due to parathyroid gland injury: The parathyroid glands are separate from the thyroid gland and regulate calcium levels in the body. Complications involving the parathyroid glands can occur during thyroid surgery leading to postoperative hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Infections: Infections can occur as complications after thyroid surgery, but they are not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is primarily related to the excessive release of thyroid hormones into the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.

 

Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:

 

  1. High fever
  2. Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  3. Elevated blood pressure
  4. Extreme agitation and restlessness
  5. Profuse sweating
  6. Tremors and shaking
  7. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  8. Delirium or confusion
  9. Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  10. Coma (in severe cases)

 

Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.

 

The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

questions.text: A patient was admitted after a road traffic accident and later put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes to verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command – 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously – 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, as given here, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the lesion as shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuropathic ulcer

 

  • The provided image indicates the presence of a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Neuropathic ulcers, also known as trophic ulcers, are the result of nerve damage, typically in individuals with conditions like diabetes or peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are often painless and can develop on the soles of the feet or other areas subject to pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial insufficiency: Arterial insufficiency ulcers are typically caused by poor blood circulation, often due to arterial disease. They often occur on the feet, toes, or lower legs and can appear as painful, pale wounds with well-defined edges. Other signs of ischemia are seen

 

 

Option C. Venous ulcers: Venous ulcers are typically caused by venous insufficiency, which leads to poor blood circulation in the legs. These ulcers often appear near the ankles and are characterized by swelling, redness, and sometimes pain.

 

 

Option D. Tuberculous ulcers: Tuberculous ulcers are a manifestation of tuberculosis infection in the skin. They are characterized by the presence of nodules or ulcers with undermined edges and a necrotic center.

 

 

Tuberculous ulcer with typical bluish undermined margins overlying sternal tuberculosis focus  

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuropathic ulcers result from peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation over pressure points leads to unnoticed minor wounds or cuts, eventually developing into ulcers.
  • Features of neuropathic ulcers include painless, punched out ulcers with regular margins, commonly located on the plantar surface of the foot.
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with a painless breast lump measuring 6.2 X 4.5 cm in the left upper outer quadrant and no axillary nodes. Core cut biopsy showed ductal carcinoma in situ. She underwent tumor resection with adequate margins and postoperative H&E showed DCIS with intermediate-grade necrosis and with 6-mm clearance on margins. What would be the next step in treatment? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

According to Silverstein Van Nuys prognostic index which is used for DCIS, the total score is 9, and the patient would require adjuvant radiotherapy.

 

Age: 43 years (score 2), size: 62mm (score 3), clearance margin: 6mm (score 2) with intermediate-grade necrosis (score 2).

 

The Silverstein Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a prognostic tool used in the management of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and the VNPI helps guide treatment decisions by assessing the risk of local recurrence.

 

The VNPI combines three significant predictors of local recurrence:

 

  1. Tumor size: The size of the DCIS lesion.
  2. Margin width: The width of clear tissue margins around the tumor after surgical resection.
  3. Pathologic classification: The histopathological characteristics of the DCIS, including features like grade and necrosis.

 

Scores on the VNPI typically range from 1 (best prognosis) to 3 (worst prognosis), with higher scores indicating a higher risk of local recurrence

 

The VNPI assists oncologists and surgeons in determining the appropriate treatment approach for patients with DCIS. For example, patients with a lower VNPI score may be candidates for less aggressive treatment, while those with a higher score may require more intensive therapies such as radiation therapy or mastectomy.

 

Score <7: No further treatment

 

Score 7-9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

Score >9: Simple mastectomy

questions.text: Which type of renal calculi is resistant to Extracorporal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL)? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystine

 

Cystine stones are resistant to extracorporal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) due to their hardness. Cystine, brushite, and calcium oxalate monohydrate stones are the most refractory to SWL fragmentation, with cystine and brushite being the most resistant.

 

Cystine stones are known to be resistant to ESWL. These stones are composed of cystine, an amino acid, and they have a dense and crystalline structure that makes them less responsive to shock wave treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Struvite: Struvite stones are generally responsive to ESWL. They often contain magnesium and ammonia and can be fragmented successfully with shock waves. However, when they attain large size and form staghorn shape, ESWL is not performed.

 

Option C. Calcium oxalate dihydrate: ESWL is often effective for calcium oxalate dihydrate stones. These stones are one of the most common types, and their composition typically allows for successful fragmentation with shock waves.

 

Option D. Uric Acid: Uric acid stones are also responsive to ESWL. These stones are composed of uric acid crystals and can be effectively broken down using shock wave lithotripsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the most common method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 2 cm in size can be treated with this form of treatment.

 

Complications: Infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma.

 

Contraindications: Obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients on oral anticoagulants.

 

Note: Stone fragments collecting in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the surgeon with a recurrent inguinal hernia. The surgeon decides to perform a hernioplasty, and the patient inquiries about the most appropriate type of mesh to be used. The surgeon wants to ensure that the patient is aware of the various types of meshes that can be used in hernioplasty. Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lightweight mesh with large pores

 

Lightweight meshes with large pores are considered the most appropriate choice for hernioplasty. They provide adequate support to repair the hernia while allowing for better tissue integration and reduced inflammation. This type of mesh is associated with lower postoperative pain and discomfort.

 

Heavyweight mesh:

 

  • Heavyweight meshes are typically not recommended for hernioplasty because they can lead to increased inflammation, tissue response, and a higher risk of complications. They may cause stiffness and discomfort in the area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate mesh to use in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.
  • Lightweight meshes induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, leading to better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • Meshes with large pores allow for increased soft tissue ingrowth and exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging. This results in less adhesion, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • “Meshes with thinner strands and larger spaces (pores) between them are preferred because they have better tissue integration, less contracture, less foreign body reaction, more flexibility and improved comfort.” Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1063.
  • Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological, with synthetic meshes made from Polypropylene, Polyester, or PTFE.

choices.text: Third part of duodenum is compressed
Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about superior mesenteric artery syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

 

In superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome, the aortomesenteric angle is reduced to less than 25 degrees, which normally is between 38-65 degrees.

 

This statement is incorrect. In SMAS, the angle between the SMA and aorta is typically less than 20 to 25 degrees, not more than 70 degrees. The narrowing of this angle contributes to the compression of the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Third part of duodenum is compressed: This statement is correct. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome involves the compression of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA and the aorta.

 

Option C. Surgical management is by Duodenojejunostomy: This statement is correct. One of the surgical treatments for SMAS is Duodenojejunostomy, which involves creating an opening between the duodenum and the jejunum to bypass the compressed area.

 

Option D. Also known as Wilkie's Syndrome: This statement is correct. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome is also known as Wilkie's Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMA syndrome, also called Wilkie's syndrome, is characterized by an obstruction of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA due to compression against fixed retroperitoneal structures. Symptoms include episodic epigastric pain associated with vomiting.

 

 

 

SMA syndrome is associated with:

 

  • Rapid growth during childhood
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the GIT
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta

 

Abdominal CT angiography is the investigation of choice.

 

Treatment involves measures to promote weight gain like NJ feeds, which will lead to widening to aortomesenteric angle (due to deposition of fat). If it fails, then a duodeno-jejunal bypass is done.

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He has chest trauma, a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. The patient is conscious but only able to speak in short phrases. On examination, there is hyperresonance on the affected side of the chest. What should be your next immediate step in managing this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female victim of RTA presents to the ER. On examination, GCS is 15/15, heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is tympanic on percussion with decreased breath sounds on auscultation. The left chest appears normal. But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen is soft. The probable diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension Pneumothorax

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability, tympanic note (hyper-resonant) on percussion, and decreased breath sounds on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased pressure in the chest cavity. This condition can compress the lungs and the great vessels in the chest, causing respiratory distress, hypotension, elevated JVP, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. Tympanic percussion note over the right chest is consistent with air in the pleural space. Ecchymosis (bruising) over the chest wall can result from trauma and rib fractures associated with tension pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade typically presents with symptoms such as hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins (Jugular Venous Pressure - JVP). While elevated JVP is mentioned in the scenario, the other symptoms associated with cardiac tamponade, such as muffled heart sounds and hypotension, are not present.

 

Option C. Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion involves the accumulation of fluid around the heart. While it can cause elevated JVP, it typically presents with other cardiac symptoms, such as muffled heart sounds and chest pain. The scenario does not mention these cardiac-specific symptoms.

 

Option D. Massive hemothorax: Massive hemothorax refers to a significant accumulation of blood in the pleural space. It can cause decreased breath sounds, but it is not typically associated with a tympanic percussion note or elevated JVP unless there is concurrent tension pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear is either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e., air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately causes collapse of the affected lung.

 

It is characterized by:

 

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distention
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of injury
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

 

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment must never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation. Management includes:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location is at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.

choices.text: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.text: Proper functioning of an ICD tube is checked by: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oscillation of water column in the tube

 

Functioning of the ICD tube can be confirmed by seeing the column of water in the chest tube oscillate up and down during respiration.

 

The oscillation or fluctuation of the water column in the water seal chamber of an ICD tube is a key indicator of proper functioning. This movement indicates that there is a patent (open) airway between the pleural space and the water seal, allowing air and fluid to exit the pleural cavity and preventing air from re-entering during inhalation. It's a visual confirmation that the ICD is effectively draining the pleural space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain: While air bubbles can sometimes be seen in the water seal chamber of an ICD system, their presence does not necessarily indicate proper functioning.

 

Option C. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable information about the position and placement of the ICD tube, it is not typically used as the primary method for checking its ongoing functioning. X-rays are often performed initially after tube insertion to confirm placement.

 

Option D. Auscultation: Auscultation can help assess lung sounds and detect any abnormalities, but it may not be the most direct method for checking the functioning of an ICD tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube is a thin, plastic tube that's inserted into the pleural space. The pleural space is the area between the chest wall and the lungs. 

 

The ICD tube is used to drain abnormal collections in the pleural cavity. It helps remove: Air (pneumothorax), Blood (hemothorax), Fluid (pleural effusion or hydrothorax, Chyle (chylothorax, Purulence (empyema. 

 

The ICD tube creates negative pressure in the chest cavity, which allows the lung to re-expand.

questions.text: A patient undergoes thyroid surgery, and their surgeon is aiming to minimize nerve injury during the procedure. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Marginal mandibular nerve

 

The marginal mandibular nerve is located in the lower part of the face, near the mandible. It is not directly associated with thyroid surgery and is far less likely to be injured during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is one of the most critical nerves to be cautious of during thyroid surgery. It runs near or through the thyroid gland and is vulnerable to injury in region of Berry’s ligament.

 

Option B. Ansa cervicalis: The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop formed by cervical spinal nerves. While it may be in the vicinity of thyroid surgery, it is less likely to be directly affected by the procedure compared to other nearby nerves like the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: The external laryngeal nerve is also in the vicinity of thyroid surgery and is most commonly injured during thyroid surgery. Its main function is to supply the cricothyroid muscle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The marginal mandibular nerve is the nerve least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery.
  • The nerve is high up, closer to the mandibular margin.
  • The ansa cervicalis may be injured if the strap muscles are not cut high enough during surgery.
  • The superior laryngeal nerve may be injured near the superior pole of the thyroid.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve may be injured if dissection is done below the cricoid cartilage or near the tracheoesophageal groove

questions.text: Which of the following given cancers rarely metastasize to the liver? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prostate

 

Prostate Cancers rarely metastasize to the liver.

 

Prostate cancer tends to metastasize to bones via periprostatic venous plexus (Bateson) rather than the liver. Bone metastases are a hallmark of advanced prostate cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colon: Colon cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver. The liver is one of the most common sites of metastasis for colon cancer, and it frequently spreads to the liver through the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Breast: Breast cancer can metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases in breast cancer are not uncommon, and the liver is considered a potential site of spread for breast cancer cells.

 

Option D. Melanoma: Melanoma is known for its propensity to metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases are common in advanced melanoma cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common malignant tumors of the liver are metastasis. The liver is a common site of metastases from gastrointestinal tumors because of dissemination via the portal venous system. The most relevant such metastatic tumor of the liver to the surgeon is colorectal cancer because of the well-documented potential for long-term survival after its complete resection.

 

The more frequent primary sites include carcinomas of the colon, pancreas, lung, and breast in adults, and neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, and rhabdomyosarcoma in pediatric patients. Although the origin of the tumor is often known when metastases are biopsied, carcinomas of the pancreas, stomach, and lung are particularly notorious for being occult primary neoplasms.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient was brought to the ER after RTA, her RR is 22/min, BP is 90/60mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the right side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What would be the appropriate management in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

 

The given scenario of tachypnea, hypotension, hyper-resonance and x ray showing absent right broncho-vascular markings is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

This option correctly addresses the likely diagnosis of a pneumothorax. The initial needle insertion can decompress the tension pneumothorax, and subsequent placement of an intercostal drain allows for continuous drainage of pleural air or fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS: This option suggests inserting a needle into the 5th ICS to relieve tension pneumothorax, which can occur due to trauma. While this can be a life-saving procedure, the presence of hyper-resonance on examination suggests a pneumothorax, but it does not address the drainage of pleural fluid, which is the primary concern in this case.

 

Option C. Aspiration of the pleural fluid: Aspiration of pleural fluid may be indicated in cases of pleural effusion, but it does not address the likely pneumothorax seen in this patient's presentation.

 

Option D. No intervention needed: With the patient's clinical presentation, including respiratory distress, low blood pressure, and hyper-resonance, intervention is indeed needed. Failure to intervene could lead to worsening respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening consequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension pneumothorax usually occurs due to trauma, such as a rib fracture, a puncture wound, or chest surgery, but it can also develop spontaneously in patients with underlying lung diseases, such as emphysema or cystic fibrosis.
  • Immediate treatment of tension pneumothorax is essential to prevent respiratory and cardiac arrest. The first step is to perform needle decompression, which involves inserting a large-bore needle into the affected side of the chest to release the trapped air in the triangle of safety. After that, a chest tube is inserted to further drain the air and prevent the reoccurrence of a pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol use presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, the patient has tenderness and guarding in the upper epigastrium. The chest x-ray is normal. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum Lipase

 

Serum lipase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas. Elevated levels of serum lipase are a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. It is a critical diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis in a patient with symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Upper GI endoscopy is used to visualize the upper gastrointestinal tract, which may help diagnose conditions like peptic ulcers or esophagitis. However, in this case, the symptoms and clinical findings are more indicative of acute pancreatitis rather than upper GI issues.

 

Option B. Alcohol breath test: An alcohol breath test is used to detect recent alcohol consumption. While the patient has a history of heavy alcohol use, this test won't provide information about the current medical condition, such as pancreatitis.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): A contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) can be a valuable tool for confirming the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and assessing its severity. However, in many cases, a serum lipase test is ordered first because it's a quicker and less invasive way to diagnose acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abdominal pain with recurrent vomiting in a chronic alcoholic with upper epigastric guarding is highly suggestive of pancreatitis.
  • A normal erect chest x-ray suggests that there is no pneumoperitoneum, effectively ruling out perforation.
  • In this setting, the main differential diagnosis to consider is pancreatitis.
  • The next appropriate investigation would be a serum lipase test to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with a hard painless testicular swelling. There were no inguinal, intra-abdominal or mediastinal lymph nodes on CT scan. The blood workup showed AFP levels of > 3000. USG shows uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis. The next line of management is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High inguinal orchidectomy  

 

This is the correct choice. In a young male presenting with a hard, painless testicular swelling and significantly elevated AFP levels (>3000), along with findings of uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis on ultrasound (USG), there is a high suspicion of testicular cancer, particularly a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT). High inguinal orchidectomy is the standard initial surgical approach for the diagnosis and treatment of testicular cancer. The removed testicle is sent for pathological examination to confirm the diagnosis and determine the specific type of tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Core needle trucut biopsy: Core needle biopsy is contraindicate for testicular masses because it carries the risk of tumor spread or seeding along the biopsy tract.

 

Option C. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): FNAC is also not the preferred option for testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding and difficulties in obtaining an accurate diagnosis for testicular cancer.

 

Option D. Whole body PET/CT: Whole body PET/CT is typically used for staging and evaluating the extent of cancer after a diagnosis is confirmed. It is not the initial step in diagnosing a testicular mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given features that point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) in stage I of the tumor. In a case of painless swelling of the testis, a testicular tumor should be suspected. The associated rise in AFP level points toward a diagnosis of NSGCT although tissue diagnosis is required to confirm the nature of the tumor. But tissue diagnosis is not a prerequisite for treatment, and hence, based on the available evidence a high inguinal orchidectomy is done in this case. Further treatment is followed up based on the findings of the excisional biopsy.

 

  • NSGCTs are not radiosensitive, but they are highly sensitive to combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy). Up to 30% of NSGCT patients with stage I disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse if surveillance alone is done after orchidectomy.
  • Accordingly, some NSGCTs with good prognoses can be managed by surveillance protocols (using regular CT scanning and tumor marker measurement), with the more high-risk cases receiving chemotherapy.
  • For NSGCTs a 5-year survival rate of more than 90% is achievable in patients with good prognosis tumors, while for more advanced tumors, the 5-year survival rate is about 60%.

questions.text: In a Preoperative surgical safety Checklist, which of the following is not a component? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Signature of the doctor

 

In a preoperative patient surgical safety checklist, doctor's signature is not needed.

 

the signature of the doctor, is not typically a component of the surgical safety checklist. Instead, the checklist focuses on verifying critical safety elements like patient consent, equipment functionality, and instrument sterility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Consent: Ensuring that informed consent has been obtained from the patient is a crucial component of preoperative safety checklists. It confirms that the patient has been informed about the procedure, risks, and alternatives and has given their consent for the surgery.

 

Option C. Functioning pulse oximeter: Checking the functioning of medical equipment like a pulse oximeter is an important step in preoperative safety. It ensures that necessary monitoring devices are in working order to monitor the patient's vital signs during surgery.

 

Option D. Sterility of instruments: Verifying the sterility of surgical instruments is essential to prevent infections during surgery. It ensures that all instruments that will come into contact with the patient are properly sterilized and safe for use.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: First assessment with sonography in trauma
Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

questions.text: The acronym FAST refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focused assessment with sonography in trauma

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FAST stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma and is a non-invasive, rapid bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen.
  • It is used to evaluate patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries and can be performed within 2-4 minutes.
  • The subxiphoid transverse view is used to assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries.
  • The longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant is used to assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch.
  • The longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant is used to assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • The transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region are used to assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.
  • eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: A condition requires the surgery depicted in the image shown below. Which of the following is not usually seen associated with this condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Absent kidney

 

The image depicts a Roux-en-Y anastomosis between jejunum and liver (hepatic duct) suggestive of Kasai procedure or hepatico-porto-jejunostomy. This is done for biliary atresia. Several other congenital anomalies are associated with it, except absent kidney.

 

Absence of a kidney is not typically associated with biliary atresia, which is a condition where the bile ducts outside and inside the liver are scarred and blocked.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatic artery anomalies: Hepatic artery anomalies can be seen in some cases of biliary atresia. The hepatic artery supplies blood to the liver, and anomalies in this artery can complicate surgical procedures.

 

Option C. Malrotation of gut: Malrotation of the gut can coexist in some cases.

 

Option D. Polysplenia: Polysplenia can be associated with biliary atresia in some cases. Polysplenia means having multiple spleens, and it can occur as part of a more complex set of congenital anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image is of Porto-enterostomy procedure which is done for extra-hepatic biliary atresia. Associated anomalies occur in about 20% of cases and include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

 

Portoenterostomy, also known as the Kasai procedure, is a surgical treatment for a condition called biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a rare and serious liver disease that affects neonates. In this condition, the bile ducts (intra/extrahepatic) are obliterated at birth.

 

 

The Portoenterostomy procedure involves the surgical creation of a new pathway for bile to flow from the liver into the small intestine. This is done by connecting a loop of the jejunum directly to the liver, allowing bile to bypass the blocked or absent bile ducts. The goal of the procedure is to restore bile flow and prevent liver damage, as untreated biliary atresia can lead to liver failure. Ideal management of high grades of biliary atresia (Kasai type 3) is liver transplant.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presented with burns injury. She is covered with burns on her head and neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45%

 

To calculate the percentage of burns, the "Rule of Nines" is commonly used in medicine. According to this rule, each area of the body is assigned a percentage value.

 

For example, the head and neck are typically assigned 9%, each upper limb is assigned 9% (18% total for both), and the front and back of the chest are assigned 18%. When we add these percentages together, we get a total of 45% burns.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 45% according to Wallace's rule of nine.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Burns on the head & neck would account for 9% of burns.
  • Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%
  • Burns on both sides of the chest would account for 18%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 9+18+18 = 45%

 

Wallace's rule of nine:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male arrives at the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient's vital signs are stable, and a focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is ordered. Which condition is least likely to be diagnosed using FAST? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retroperitoneal hematoma

 

Detecting retroperitoneal hematoma is challenging with FAST because it is located deep within the abdominal cavity, behind the peritoneum. FAST primarily focuses on the pericardium, pleura, and peritoneum, making it less suitable for detecting retroperitoneal injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericardial Effusion: FAST is effective at detecting pericardial effusions. It involves examining the pericardial sac for fluid accumulation with probe placed in epigastrium.
