Option B. Pneumothorax: eFAST can detect pneumothorax to some extent by visualizing the pleural space for the presence of air.

 

Option D. Renal Injury: FAST can detect renal injuries by examining the perinephric space for signs of bleeding or fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Among the given options, FAST is the least effective in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma due to poor sensitivity of ultrasound for detecting it.
  • CT scan is the preferred diagnostic tool for retroperitoneal injuries, but it should only be performed on hemodynamically stable patients.
  • FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma and is a non-invasive, rapid bedside test used to detect free fluid in the abdomen using sonography.
  • The patient is positioned supine, and a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used to scan the subxiphoid, right and left upper quadrants, and suprapubic region to assess potential thoracoabdominal injuries.
  • eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: Fr with respect to size of Foley's catheter refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Outer Diameter

 

Fr, short for French, is a unit of measurement used for the outer diameter of a Foley catheter. It is a common way to denote the size of the catheter, especially in medical and healthcare settings. The French scale is based on a 3:1 ratio, where one French unit (Fr) is approximately equal to 0.33 millimeters in outer diameter. For example, a Foley catheter with a size of 16 Fr has an outer diameter of approximately 5.3 millimeters.

 

Therefore, the diameter of a catheter in millimeters can be determined by dividing the French size by 3.

questions.text: A 27-year-old accountant underwent parotidectomy following which she developed lower lip paralysis. This probably occurred because of an injury to which of the following structures? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mandibular branch of facial nerve

 

The mandibular branch of the facial nerve, also known as the marginal mandibular branch, supplies motor fibers to the muscles responsible for lower lip movement. During a parotidectomy, there is a risk of injuring the nearby facial nerve branches, including the mandibular branch. Damage to this branch can lead to lower lip paralysis or weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead and is not related to the lower lip.

 

Option B. Cervical branch of facial nerve: The cervical branch of the facial nerve innervates certain neck muscles and is also not related to the lower lip.

 

Option C. Parotid duct: The parotid duct, also known as Stensen's duct, carries saliva from the parotid gland to the mouth. Injury to this duct could result in salivary leakage from wound (salivary fistula).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lower lip paralysis is a result of an injury to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve.
  • During parotidectomy, the facial nerve may be at risk of injury since it passes through the parotid gland.
  • The branches of the facial nerve include the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical branches.

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET) is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

Most common type of PNET seen is: Insulinoma

 

Insulinomas are the most common type of PNETs. They produce excess insulin, leading to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) in affected individuals. Insulinomas are typically benign and occur more frequently than other types of PNETs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma: Gastrinoma is a type of PNET that produces excess gastrin hormone. It is associated with a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Gastrinomas are relatively less common than insulinomas.

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinomas are rare PNETs that produce excess somatostatin hormone. They can occur in the pancreas or other parts of the digestive system. They are less common than insulinomas.

 

Option D. VIPoma: VIPomas, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome or pancreatic cholera, are PNETs that produce vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). These tumors are relatively rare compared to insulinomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PNETs are a rare type of pancreatic tumor that originate from neuroendocrine cells in the pancreas.
  • PNETs are classified as either functioning or non-functioning based on their ability to produce hormones.
  • Diagnosis of PNETs typically involves imaging studies such as CT or MRI, as well as biopsy or blood tests to measure hormone levels.
  • Treatment options for PNETs may include surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy, depending on the size, location, and type of tumor.

 

Insulinoma:

 

  • The investigation of choice for insulinoma 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.
  • Medical management:
    • Octreotide
  • Surgical management - Enucleation

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with chest pain and shortness of breath. Further investigation reveals a mediastinal mass on imaging studies. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation. What is the most common type of tumor found in the anterior mediastinum? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The most common anterior mediastinal tumor is thymoma, while posterior mediastinal tumor is neurogenic tumor.

 

The most common mediastinal tumor in children is neurogenic tumor.

 

  • Thymomas are tumors that originate from the thymus gland located in the mediastinum.
  • They account for a significant portion of mediastinal tumors and are the most common type.
  • Thymomas can vary in terms of malignancy, with some being benign (noncancerous) and others being malignant (cancerous).
  • These tumors can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and other symptoms when they grow and press on nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurogenic: Neurogenic tumors, which originate from nerve tissue, are another type of mediastinal tumor found in posterior mediastinum

 

  • Examples of neurogenic tumors include neuroblastoma and ganglioneuroma.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas can occur in the mediastinum but are less frequent than thymomas.

 

  • Lymphomas originate from lymphatic tissue and can be Hodgkin lymphoma or non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option D. Bronchial cyst: Bronchial cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can develop in the mediastinum but are relatively rare compared to thymomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, thymoma is the most common type of tumor found in the mediastinum, and it originates from the thymus gland. When a patient presents with chest pain and shortness of breath and is found to have a mediastinal mass on imaging studies, thymoma is a likely consideration among other possible mediastinal tumors

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after an RTA. He has suffered chest trauma, has respiratory rate of 44/min and BP is 90/40 mm of hg. He is conscious and speaks single words. There is a hyper-resonance on percussion on the involved side of his chest. What will be your immediate next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercoastal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in managing this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrograffin follow-through

 

The given clinical history along with the radiograph showing the triple bubble sign implies a diagnosis of jejunal atresia. A contrast study should be the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies.

 

A Gastrograffin follow-through is a radiological procedure that involves the administration of contrast material (Gastrograffin) followed by a series of X-rays to visualize the gastrointestinal tract. An alternate investigation would be CT with contrast (not given in options). In cases of recurrent bilious vomiting, it is a valuable diagnostic tool to assess for intestinal obstruction, such as malrotation or other anatomical abnormalities. It helps determine if there are any blockages or abnormalities in the intestines that may be causing the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Performing an endoscopy is generally not the first-line investigation for a neonate with recurrent bilious vomiting where an obstructive GI pathology is likely.

 

Option C. USG abdomen: An ultrasound (USG) of the abdomen can provide useful information in some cases, but it may not be the most appropriate initial investigation for recurrent bilious vomiting when there is a need to evaluate the entire gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option D. Explorative laparotomy: Explorative laparotomy, which involves surgery to explore the abdominal cavity, is a more invasive option and is typically considered when other diagnostic methods have failed to provide a clear diagnosis or when there is a strong suspicion of a surgical emergency. It is not the first-line choice in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small bowel atresia’s present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth.

 

  • Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia
  • Abdominal distension is more prominent with ileal atresia.

 

A small amount of pale meconium may be passed despite the atresia.

 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction

 

In most cases of jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is performed. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury on his arm. The lesion was pink, oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following would be the most appropriate management? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collagen dressing

 

Scald injury (damage due to contact with hot liquids) that appears pink in colour, has oozing, and pain is suggestive of a 2nd-degree superficial burn (i.e., partial-thickness burn). Collagen dressing is the most appropriate management for this injury.

 

Collagen dressings are an appropriate choice for partial-thickness burn wounds and scald injuries. They provide several advantages, including promoting wound healing, reducing pain, and helping to maintain a moist environment, which is conducive to tissue repair. Collagen dressings can be especially helpful in managing painful wounds like scald injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silver Sulphadiazine Cream Dressing: Silver sulfadiazine cream is commonly used for burn wounds. However, in the case of a scald injury like the one described (pink, oozing, and painful), silver sulfadiazine cream may not be the first choice. This cream is used for second degree deep and third degree burns.

 

Option B. Excision and Grafting: Excision and grafting are typically reserved for severe burn injuries that involve full-thickness damage to the skin and underlying tissues. In the case of a pink, oozing, and painful scald injury, which is likely partial-thickness, excision and grafting may be overly aggressive and not necessary.

 

Option C. Paraffin Gauze Dressing: Paraffin gauze dressings are often used for burn wounds. They provide a non-adherent surface and help maintain a moist wound environment. While this dressing may be suitable, collagen dressings (Option D) are better at promoting wound healing and tissue repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best dressing for burn wounds is skin; collagen is a good substitute for skin, especially in partial-thickness burns. For full-thickness burns, sequential excision and grafting must be considered.

 

Initial treatment for burns includes cleaning the burnt areas and removing loose dead skin. Blisters are de-roofed and an appropriate dressing is applied.

 

Biological dressing (collagen dressings, amniotic membrane, etc.) is the preferred dressing material, especially in partial thickness burns.

 

If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream may be applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be used judiciously and reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of doom? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iliopubic tract

 

Iliopubic tract does not form a boundary of the triangle of doom.

 

The Iliopubic tract is not a boundary of the Triangle of Doom. It is not directly associated with this anatomical region. It forms the lateral boundary of triangle of pain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vas deferens: It runs medially and is considered one of the key landmarks in this anatomical region.

 

Option B. Peritoneal Reflection: It forms the inferior boundary of this anatomical triangle.

 

Option D. Spermatic vessels: The spermatic vessels are one of the boundaries of the Triangle of Doom. They are located laterally and are an important landmark in this anatomical triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triangle of doom is bounded-

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

Apex is oriented superiorly at the internal ring

 

The contents of the space are-

 

  • External iliac vessels

 

Note: Staples must be avoided in this region during hernia repair due to the risk of injury to the vessels which might cause severe hemorrhage.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5 cm renal calculus causing severe flank pain. It is detected as a staghorn calculus. What is the best management? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

 

PCNL is the preferred treatment for large and complex kidney stones, especially Staghorn calculi. It involves making a small incision in the patient's back to access the kidney directly. A nephroscope is then used to remove or break up the stone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller pieces, making them easier to pass. While ESWL is effective for smaller kidney stones, it may not be as successful for very large (> 2 cm) and complex Staghorn calculi.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to reach the stone in the ureter or renal pelvis. While it can be effective for ureteric stones, it may not be the best choice for Staghorn calculi, especially those larger than 4 cm.

 

Option D. Hydrotherapy: This can be tried for stones up to 5 mm in size. Larger stones would get obstructed in ureter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to remove large kidney stones. The following are some of the indications for PCNL:

 

  1. Large or complex kidney stones (> 2 cm) or hard stones (Cysteine) that cannot be treated with other minimally invasive procedures such as shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) or ureteroscopy.
  2. Staghorn calculi (large branching stones) that occupy a significant portion of the kidney.
  3. Stones that are associated with renal obstruction or infection.

choices.text: To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal
To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day three, the patient returned to the hospital and was febrile. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. Next best step is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insert pigtail catheter for drainage

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

 

The next best step after imaging would be to control inflammation by

 

  • Drainage of fluid collection (Pigtail insertion and drainage) and
  • Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics

 

This is the most appropriate next step in managing a subhepatic collection. A pigtail catheter is inserted percutaneously under imaging guidance to drain the collection. This helps in both diagnosing and treating any infection or abscess that may have developed after the surgery. It allows for drainage of the accumulated fluid and may be accompanied by sending the drained fluid for culture and sensitivity testing. This step is less invasive than re-exploration and allows for targeted management of the collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal: While antibiotics may be considered in some postoperative cases, the presence of a collection along with fever suggests an infection or abscess, making antibiotics alone an inadequate treatment.

 

Option B. To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube: Re-exploration of the surgical wound and insertion of a T-tube is a more invasive approach and is not the first-line option for managing a postoperative collection.

 

Option D. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is typically used to evaluate and treat conditions of the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts and is not the primary intervention for managing a postoperative collection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bile duct injury

 

  • Usually manifests in the postoperative period

 

Clinical features

 

  • Fever
  • Increasing abdominal pain
  • Jaundice
  • Bile leakage from an incision

 

Diagnosis

 

Imaging: Ultrasonography

 

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree

 

Treatment Strategy

 

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
  • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
  • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of entire biliary anatomy
  • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
  • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: The flap shown in the picture is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serratus anterior flap

 

The given image shows a serratus anterior flap. The serratus anterior flap is a highly reliable flap which has a consistently long pedicle. Its anatomy allows coverage of complex wounds. The underlying rib can be included as a myoosseous flap to expand the versatility of this flap.

 

  • The serratus anterior flap is a reconstructive surgical technique that uses the serratus anterior muscle, which is located between the ribs and scapula.
  • This flap is often used for chest wall reconstruction and breast reconstruction procedures.
  • It provides good vascularization and can be used to cover defects in the chest and axillary regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoral Myo-cutaneous Flap: The pectoral myo-cutaneous flap is a surgical technique that utilizes tissue from the pectoral muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is commonly used in reconstruction after resection of oral malignancies.
  • This flap can provide a good blood supply and a natural appearance.

 

Option C. TRAM Flap (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The TRAM flap is a reconstructive technique that uses tissue from the lower abdominal wall, including the rectus abdominis muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is often employed in breast reconstruction, providing a large amount of tissue.
  • There are two types: pedicled TRAM flap (retains its blood supply through the rectus muscle) and free TRAM flap (microvascular reconstruction).

 

Option D. VRAM Flap (Vertical Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The VRAM flap is similar to the TRAM flap but uses tissue from the vertical orientation of the rectus abdominis muscle.

 

  • It is also used in breast reconstruction and abdominal wall reconstruction.
  • Like the TRAM flap, it can be pedicled or free, depending on the surgical technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flap surgery is a type of plastic surgery that uses tissues from another part of the body to close open wounds while having its own blood supply.
  • The site from which the tissue is obtained is called the donor site, while the site where the tissue is transferred is called the recipient site. Flaps may be of soft tissue, skin, muscle, bone, fat or fascia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has a lesion over the face as shown below. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BCC (Basal cell carcinoma)

 

The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, especially in older individuals with sun exposure. It often appears as a pearly or waxy bump with central depression, which can bleed easily. Itching is also a common symptom associated with BCC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatofibrosarcoma: Dermatofibrosarcoma is a rare, slow-growing soft tissue tumor that typically presents as a painless, raised, flesh-colored or brownish lesion. It does not commonly cause bleeding or itching.

 

 

Option B. Marjolin's Ulcer: Marjolin's ulcer refers to a malignant transformation of a chronic non-healing wound, scar, or ulcer. It is often associated with long-standing inflammation or trauma. While it can present with bleeding, it typically doesn't cause itching as a primary symptom.

 

 

Option D. Naevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign skin lesion. While moles can occasionally be itchy, they do not usually cause bleeding unless they are irritated or traumatized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is an epithelial tumor that arises from basal cells layer of epidermis. It is the most common type of skin cancer. Most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Clinically it can present either as nodular or pigmented BCC. Features of nodular BCC are:

 

  1. Small, slowly growing pearly nodule
  2. Tortuous telangiectatic vessels on the surface
  3. Rolled borders
  4. Central crusting

 

The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

questions.text: While performing triage of children who are victims of a school bus accident, which one will you attend to first? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Airway Obstruction

 

The most appropriate answer is airway obstruction.

 

Maintaining a patent airway is crucial for the survival of any trauma patient, especially children. An airway obstruction can quickly lead to severe respiratory distress and, if left untreated, can result in death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 4 Shock: While shock is a critical condition, attending to airway obstruction takes precedence because it directly impacts oxygenation, which is vital for life. Treating shock without addressing airway obstruction may not be effective.

 

Option C. Flail Chest: Flail chest is a serious chest injury, but it may not be an immediate threat to the airway. It should be assessed and treated promptly but is not the first priority compared to airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Severe head injury: Head injuries are also critical, but immediate attention to airway obstruction is necessary to ensure the child's ability to breathe and maintain oxygenation. Head injuries can be assessed and managed after ensuring a clear airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage decisions are to be made by deciding which injuries constitute the greatest immediate threat to life.

 

In general, airway problems are more rapidly lethal than breathing problems › circulation problems > neurologic injuries.

questions.text: During the insertion of a Ryle’s tube, what is the best position for a conscious patient to be in? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

choices.text: Hemodynamically unstable patient should not be sent for CT scan
All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only
X-ray of the pelvis is done in primary survey
X-rays in primary survey may also be done in pregnant women

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only

 

Chest X-ray and X-ray pelvis are taken in AP view in the adjuncts to the primary survey of a trauma patient.

 

This statement is false. Chest X-rays are often a standard part of the primary survey to assess for chest injuries and potential life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax or hemothorax, however AP view is commonly used in the primary survey. PA view requires patient to be standing, which is usually not possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemodynamically unstable patients should not be sent for CT scans: This statement is true. Hemodynamically unstable patients are in a critical condition, and their immediate management should prioritize stabilizing their condition.

 

Option C. X-ray of the pelvis is done in the primary survey: This statement is true. Pelvic X-rays may be performed if pelvic injury is suspected based on clinical assessment, however they are not universally conducted in all trauma patients during the primary survey, hence considered as “adjuncts”.

 

Option D. X-rays in the primary survey may be done in pregnant women: This statement is generally true. Pregnant trauma patients should undergo imaging as needed during the primary survey to assess for injuries. However, the choice of imaging modalities and the use of shielding techniques should consider the safety of the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

 

  • Primary survey and simultaneous resuscitation - in order to identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey - proceeding to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care - developing a definitive management plan

 

ABCDE of trauma care:

 

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

 

Adjuncts to the primary survey are-

 

  • Blood - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheterization
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

 

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only in a patient stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple injuries in a motor vehicle accident. The patient is hemodynamically unstable and requires a massive blood transfusion. The physician is concerned about the potential adverse effects of the transfusion and wants to monitor the patient closely. The physician wants to confirm which of the following adverse effects is not commonly observed in patients who receive a massive blood transfusion? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

 

This is not a common adverse effect of blood transfusions. Blood transfusions are more likely to cause hypocalcemia due to citrate binding calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypocalcemia: It can occur after a massive blood transfusion because citrate, an anticoagulant used in blood storage bags, can bind to calcium, reducing its levels when the transfused blood is administered. Citrate is used to prevent blood clotting during storage but can have this effect when transfused.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: It can rarely occur after a massive blood transfusion because of dilution of recipient’s blood potassium.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: This is a potential adverse effect of a massive blood transfusion. Stored blood cells can undergo lysis leading to higher potassium levels in the blood products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypocalcemia and not Hypercalcemia is an adverse effect of massive blood transfusion.
  • Massive blood transfusion instead leads to Hypocalcemia as the anticoagulant citrate binds to calcium.

 

The complications of massive blood transfusion are:

 

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypothermia
  • Alkalosis

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought with complaints of umbilical discharge. Abdominal examination was otherwise normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) USG Abdomen

 

The given image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly with an apparent discharging sinus. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of embryonal umbilical anomalies such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step in the management of this case is USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or of fistula.

 

Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a safe and non-invasive imaging technique commonly used to evaluate abdominal conditions in pediatric patients. It is particularly useful for assessing the umbilical region and identifying any abnormalities that may be causing the umbilical discharge. USG provides real-time imaging and can help in diagnosing conditions such as umbilical granulomas, urachal abnormalities, or other underlying issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI Abdomen: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) of the abdomen is a valuable diagnostic tool for various abdominal conditions. However, in the case of a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge, an ultrasound (USG) is typically the initial imaging modality of choice. MRI is generally reserved for more complex or specific cases.

 

Option C. СЕСТ: CECT may be done after USG if further information was desired.

 

Option D. Exploratory laparotomy: Performing an exploratory laparotomy as the initial step in a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge and an otherwise normal abdominal examination would be overly aggressive and not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities:

 

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated.
  • The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct can lead to various abnormalities according to the part of the duct that is persistent.
  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel's diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near umbilicus leads to umbilical sinus, likely to be the case here.
  • Fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to enterocutaneous fistula.

questions.text: Which of these is not a feature of Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory rate > 22/ minute and PaCO2 <35mmHg

 

  • This statement does not align with the criteria for SIRS. In SIRS, an elevated respiratory rate (tachypnea) is defined as a respiratory rate greater than 20 breaths per minute or an arterial carbon dioxide partial pressure (PaCO2) less than 32 mmHg. Therefore, the option presented combines an elevated respiratory rate with an abnormally low PaCO2, which is not part of the SIRS criteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) are:

 

  • Fever (body temperature >38°C) or temperature <36°C.
  • Tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute).
  • Tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) < 32 mm Hg).
  • Leukocytosis (white blood cell count >12,000 cells/mm³), leukopenia (white blood cell count <4,000 cells/mm³), or the presence of >10% immature neutrophils (band forms) in the blood.
  • Other signs of systemic inflammation such as elevated levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) or procalcitonin.

choices.text: 10-year-old child with multi organ dysfunction syndrome
49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence
74-year-old woman with end stage renal disease

questions.text: In the case of a 37-year-old woman who has been declared brain dead and whose family has agreed to donate her organs, who would be the most suitable or optimal candidate to receive the organs? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31-year-old women with renal failure

 

This candidate is closer in age to the donor, and if her medical condition and compatibility allow for a successful kidney transplant, she may be the most suitable recipient for the kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A 10-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome: This candidate is likely in urgent need of multiple organ transplantation, and a younger recipient may generally have better long-term outcomes. However, etiology of multi-organ dysfunction is not provided, thereby the long term prognosis of the patient is uncertain.

 

Option B. A 49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence: While this candidate may benefit from a liver transplant, alcoholism can pose challenges to transplantation success. The one-month abstinence period is relatively short, and further evaluation of his liver condition and suitability for transplantation would be necessary.

 

Option C. A 74-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease: Given the age of the recipient and the fact that she has end-stage renal disease, a kidney transplant from the 37-year-old donor may not provide the best long-term outcomes. Older recipients may have a lower life expectancy, and the benefit of a kidney transplant may be less significant compared to younger recipients.

choices.text: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored
Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding retroperitoneal trauma? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically

 

Zone 2 hematoma is seen in flank region and typically related to renal injury. Zone 2 hematomas may be conserved unless they are expanding, when surgery is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively: Zone 1 hematoma refers to central zone, where likely structures injured are abdominal aorta or IVC are injured. Since these are major vascular injuries, all zone 1 hematomas should be explored.

 

Option B. Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored: Zone 3 refers to the pelvis region, and injuries in this area Should be managed conservatively with pelvic binder or external fixator. Exploration in these areas is dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible.

 

Option D. Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta: The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used during emergency laparotomies to visualize the abdominal aorta. It involves mobilizing the left sided abdominal viscera medially, which allows for better visualization of the retroperitoneum and the aorta. This maneuver can be useful in cases of trauma or other emergency situations where visualization of the aorta is necessary.

questions.text: Identify the breast condition shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mondor’s Disease

 

Mondor's disease is a rare condition characterized by superficial thrombophlebitis of the subcutaneous veins, typically in the breast or chest wall, but it can occur in other parts of the body as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget's disease: Paget's disease is an insitu lesion of nipple which presents with nipple destruction.

 

Option C. Zuska's disease: Zuska's disease, also known as chronic periductal mastitis is characterized by slit like nipple retraction after repeated inflammation of lactiferous ducts seen in smoker females.

 

Option D. Tietze syndrome: Tietze syndrome is a rare inflammatory condition that affects the cartilage of the ribs and sternum, causing pain and swelling in the affected area. The exact cause of Tietze syndrome is unknown, but it may be related to trauma, infection, or underlying autoimmune or inflammatory disorders. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, tenderness, and redness over the affected area. Treatment options may include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of Mondor's disease includes pain, tenderness, and redness over the affected area, along with a palpable cord-like structure that corresponds to the thrombosed vein.
  • The diagnosis of Mondor's disease is made by physical examination.
  • Treatment for Mondor's disease includes restriction of arm movements, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), warm compresses, and compression garments to alleviate pain and inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequent presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abdominal mass

 

The most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor is as an abdominal mass.

 

Abdominal mass is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are characterized by the development of firm, palpable masses in the abdominal wall or other abdominal structures. This is the hallmark sign of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal pain: While abdominal pain can be a symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors, it is not the most frequent presentation. These tumors often manifest as painless masses in the abdominal area.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is generally not a primary symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are primarily associated with the formation of masses rather than systemic symptoms like fever.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse: Rectal prolapse is not a common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An abdominal desmoid tumor is a tumor that arises from fibro-aponeurotic tissue in the musculoaponeurotic structures of the abdominal wall, especially below the level of the umbilicus.

 

Desmoid tumors are frequently seen to be associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) syndrome.

 

It commonly presents as a slow-growing mass and tends to infiltrate muscle in the immediate area. Eventually, it can undergo a myxomatous change and then shows an increase in size more rapidly.

 

The investigation of choice for desmoid tumor is MRI. Biopsy with immunohistochemistry can help in establishing the diagnosis. The tumors typically stain positive for

 

  • 3-catenin
  • Actin and
  • Vimentin.

 

It stains negative for cytokeratin and S-100.

 

  • Treatment includes wide excision with a margin clearance of 2.5cm to avoid recurrence. It is a completely unencapsulated fibroma and is hard to cut. The defect then requires repair using mesh to prevent hernia in the future.
  • Radiotherapy alone is an acceptable treatment option for patients with unresectable desmoid tumors
  • Prognosis is good, with no metastasis or sarcomatous change. Although they lack metastatic potential, they can be multifocal as well as locally aggressive and invasive, with a high propensity for recurrence.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling as shown. The swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. What is your diagnosis?  (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thyroglossal cyst

 

Among the given options, thyroglossal cyst is the only neck swelling which is midline, moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid.

 

Thyroglossal cysts are cystic swellings that form from the remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which is a duct that connects the developing thyroid gland to the tongue during embryonic development. These cysts often move with deglutition or tongue protrusion and are typically located in the midline of the neck, as seen in the provided image.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Branchial cysts are typically located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (upper and middle third) and do not move with deglutition. They are congenital and arise from remnants of branchial arches.

 

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: Cystic hygromas are usually found in the neck and are also congenital, usually in posterior triangle. They are caused by lymphatic malformation and do not typically move with deglutition.

 

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to enlarged lymph nodes in the neck. While lymph nodes can sometimes be palpable in the neck, they do not usually move with deglutition and are not typically cystic in nature.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other neck swellings that move with deglutition are:

 

  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

 

However, amongst these only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This occurs because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of tongue to the isthmus of the gland.

 

Sistrunk's operation is the procedure performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, along with removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

choices.text: Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice

questions.text: Before transferring the patient to the operating theatre, which of the following is necessary to do for a 60-year-old man who has been experiencing abdominal pain for the past six hours, has a BP of 84/50mmHg, RR of 26/min, saturation of 92% with 6 L of oxygen, and has extraluminal air in the abdomen on radiograph? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer 2 litres of crystalloid infusion

 

This is the correct option. The patient's low blood pressure (84/50 mmHg) and extraluminal air in the abdomen suggest a possible abdominal catastrophe, such as a perforated viscus. Administering crystalloid fluids is essential to address hypovolemia and improve blood pressure. The goal is to stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status and then perform an emergency laparotomy and repair the perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate the patient: While intubation may be necessary in some cases of severe respiratory distress or respiratory failure, it is not indicated in this situation.

 

Option B. Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice: While establishing intravenous (IV) access is important for administering fluids and medications, inserting a central venous catheter is a more invasive procedure and not the initial step. Peripheral IV access can be established quickly and is usually sufficient for initial resuscitation.

 

Option D. Verify the diagnosis with CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): While a CT scan may be necessary for confirming the diagnosis and identifying the specific issue, it is not the initial step in managing a patient in this critical condition. Stabilizing the patient's vital signs and addressing potential hypovolemia should come first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given clinical scenario, volume resuscitation is crucial for maintaining BP as the patient has no history of trauma, indicating a possible bowel perforation.
  • Peripheral large-bore cannula may be used for initial volume resuscitation, and a central venous catheter may be required if vasopressors are planned.
  • Intubation may not be necessary since the patient is maintaining saturation.
  • CT scan may not be necessary as the provisional diagnosis of bowel perforation has already been established, and the patient's vital signs should be considered.

questions.text: Which parameter is best used to monitor the adequacy of and guide fluid resuscitation in a patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Urine Output

 

Urine output is the best measure of organ perfusion and the best monitor for adequacy of fluid resuscitation.

 

Adequate end-organ perfusion is best indicated by urine output of >0.5 to 1 mL/kg/h. However, it does not give minute-to-minute values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CVP (central venous pressure): CVP is a poor reflector of preload. Central venous pressure (CVP) is the mean pressure in the superior vena cava, indicating right ventricular end-diastolic pressure or preload. Normal CVP ranges from 2 to 7 mm Hg (3 to 9 cm H20). A sick or injured patient with a CVP <3 mm Hg is presumed to be volume depleted and maybe given fluids with relative safety. However, CVP is unreliable for assessment of volume status or left ventricular function.

 

Option C. Blood pressure: Blood pressure is an important vital sign, but it alone may not provide a complete picture of a patient's fluid status. Hypotension (low blood pressure) can be a late sign of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and normotension (normal blood pressure) does not guarantee adequate tissue perfusion. The level of consciousness is an important marker for cerebral perfusion.

 

Option D. Oxygen saturation: Oxygen saturation (SpO2) measures the amount of oxygen in the blood, and while it is essential for assessing respiratory status, it is not a direct indicator of fluid balance or adequacy of fluid resuscitation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urine output is a valuable and non-invasive parameter for assessing fluid resuscitation. Adequate urine output indicates that the patient's kidneys are functioning well and that they are likely receiving an appropriate amount of fluids. It is a practical and real-time measure of the patient's response to fluid therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient undergoes surgery for a clean-contaminated wound after receiving prophylactic antibiotics. What is the expected rate of surgical site infection in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3%

 

After the administration of prophylactic antibiotics, the anticipated rate of surgical site infection in a patient with a clean contaminated wound is 3%.

 

This is a reasonable estimate for the expected rate of SSI in clean-contaminated surgical wounds. These wounds have a controlled level of contamination, and prophylactic antibiotics are given to reduce the risk of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-2%: This range represents a lower infection rate, which is more commonly associated with surgeries in clean wounds.

 

Option C. 13-20%: This range is much higher and is more typical for surgeries in contaminated or dirty wounds, where the risk of infection is significantly elevated.

 

Option D. 20-30%: This range represents a very high infection rate and is more characteristic of surgeries performed in dirty or heavily contaminated wounds. It would be unusual to expect such a high infection rate in a clean-contaminated surgical case with prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A surgical site infection (SSI) is an infection that occurs at or near a surgical incision or operative site after surgery. SSIs can range from mild to severe and can affect the skin and underlying tissues, including muscles and organs. These infections are a common complication of surgery and can lead to various health problems if not treated promptly.

 

Key characteristics and considerations related to surgical site infections (SSIs) include:

 

  1. Classification:
    • SSIs are classified into three main categories based on the timing of onset:
    • Superficial Incisional SSI: Infection occurs within 30 days after the operation and involves only the skin and subcutaneous tissues at the incision site.
    • Deep Incisional SSI: Infection also occurs within 30 days after the operation but involves deeper tissues, such as muscles and fascia, at the incision site.
    • Organ/Space SSI: Infection can occur within 30 or 90 days after the operation and affects any part of the body other than the incision area. This can include infections within the abdominal or chest cavities.
       
  2. Signs and Symptoms:
    • The symptoms of an SSI may include redness, warmth, swelling, pain, and discharge at or near the surgical site.
    • Systemic symptoms like fever, chills, and malaise can also occur if the infection is severe or has spread.
       
  3. Prevention:
    • Preventive measures are crucial in reducing the risk of SSIs. These measures include:
      • Preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis
      • Proper hand hygiene and sterile techniques during surgery
      • Maintaining a clean surgical environment
      • Adequate skin preparation before incision
      • Proper wound care and postoperative monitoring
         
  4. Treatment:
    • Treatment of an SSI typically involves antibiotics to target the specific bacteria causing the infection.
    • In some cases, additional interventions may be necessary, such as wound drainage, debridement (removal of infected tissue), or, rarely, reoperation.
       
  5. Complications:
    • If left untreated or not managed appropriately, SSIs can lead to more serious complications, such as abscess formation, cellulitis, tissue necrosis, and the spread of infection to other parts of the body.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient undergoes parotidectomy surgery to remove a tumor. During the postoperative period, the patient complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Great auricular nerve

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (specifically, the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the earlobe and the skin over the parotid gland. Damage to this nerve during parotidectomy surgery can lead to loss of sensation in the earlobe area, which could affect the patient's sensation while shaving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the external ear and the temporal region, which if injured gives rise to gustatory sweating or Frey’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Facial nerve: The facial nerve is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression, not sensation. Damage to the facial nerve during parotidectomy surgery can result in facial weakness or paralysis rather than altered sensation.

 

Option D. Marginal mandibular nerve: The marginal mandibular nerve is a branch of the facial nerve and primarily provides innervation to the lower lip. It is not typically involved in sensation during shaving.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nerves that can be injured in parotidectomy and its significance:

 

A) Auriculotemporal nerve injury – Frey’s syndrome

 

B) Great auricular nerve- loss of sensation in area of shaving

 

C) Facial nerve- facial palsy

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will be first visualized to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cecum

 

The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.

 

Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.

 

Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: Which of these is not an expected complication of Heller’s operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gas bloat syndrome

 

  • The most common surgical procedure for achalasia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy, usually performed in conjunction with an anti-reflux procedure (partial fundoplication) to prevent post-operative acid reflux (option B). 
  • During the procedure, the anterior vagus nerve can be injured (option A). Forceful myotomy may also tear the mucosa and lead to perforation (Option D).
  • Gas bloat is seen after fundoplication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injury to the vagus nerve: It can occur during dissection around the esophagus.

 

Option B. Acid reflux: It can occur especially if the myotomy is not combined with a partial fundoplication, since the LES is weakened.

 

Option D. Esophageal perforation: It can occur due to the delicate nature of the esophageal wall during the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gas bloat syndrome is more commonly associated with Nissen fundoplication, a procedure for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • It occurs when patients are unable to burp, leading to bloating and discomfort from trapped gas.
  • Thus, gas bloat syndrome is not a complication of Heller’s myotomy.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, he had pain over the right side of the hip on passive extension along with a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psoas abscess

 

The given clinical finding of pain on hip extension is “psoas sign” which is seen in inflammation of psoas like abscess or appendicitis. However, presence of mass in right lumbar makes psoas abscess more likely.

 

Psoas abscess is an infection that occurs in the psoas muscle, which is located in the lower back and can extend into the right lower quadrant. It can cause lower back pain, hip pain on passive extension, and the presence of a mass in the lumbar region, making it a likely diagnosis based on the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is an infection of the kidneys and typically presents with symptoms such as fever, flank pain, and urinary symptoms. While it can cause lower back pain, it doesn't typically result in a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Option C. Appendicitis: Appendicitis usually presents with pain in the right lower quadrant, but it doesn't typically involve lower back pain or the presence of a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Option D. Torsion of right undescended testis: Testicular torsion is a condition involving the twisting of the spermatic cord, which leads to severe testicular pain and swelling. It does not typically cause lower back pain or a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of abdominal pain and mass in the right lumbar region, with pain on passive extension of the right hip (psoas sign), points towards the diagnosis of psoas abscess.

 

The history of lower back pain needs to be evaluated with the possibility of tubercular origin to be kept in mind in this patient.

 

Treatment is usually by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with complaints of vomiting and abdominal distention. A nasogastric (NG) tube is inserted to decompress the stomach. However, the patient remains conscious and alert during the procedure. What is the best position to place the patient in during the insertion of the NG tube? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty with high fever and pain in abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. There was no past history of long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxic megacolon

 

The probable diagnosis is toxic megacolon.

 

Toxic megacolon is a severe condition characterized by acute colonic distension and systemic toxicity. It is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis. Patients with toxic megacolon can present with high fever, abdominal pain, and a history of bloody diarrhea, which aligns with the patient's symptoms in this case. The abdominal X-ray shows transverse colonic dilation > 6 cm, which is a characteristic finding in toxic megacolon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus is a condition in which a portion of the bowel twists on itself, leading to obstruction and ischemia. While it can cause abdominal pain, it typically does not present with the same systemic symptoms seen in toxic megacolon.

 

Option C. Ogilvie syndrome: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, is characterized by marked colonic dilation without a mechanical obstruction. It can cause abdominal pain and distension but does not typically present with a history of bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pneumatosis intestinalis: Pneumatosis intestinalis refers to the presence of gas within the wall of the intestine. While it can be seen on imaging studies, it is not a specific diagnosis and does not explain the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon > 6 cm. The history of bloody diarrhea and loss of haustrations are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient with ulcerative colitis point towards toxic megacolon.

 

A plain abdominal X-ray film can indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is especially valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon. The next step would be to perform a CECT abdomen to assess status of bowel and urgent exploration may be needed if ischemia or perforation is seen.

choices.text: Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was diagnosed with breast cancer of 1.2 X 1 cm with positive axillary nodes and underwent treatment for the same. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. How will you follow up the patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual mammogram

 

The most important aspect of breast cancer follow-up is regular surveillance mammograms. Annual mammograms are recommended to monitor for any signs of disease recurrence or new breast cancers. Mammograms are effective in detecting early breast cancer and remain a crucial part of long-term follow-up care for breast cancer survivors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months: Regular liver function testing (LFT) is not typically indicated for breast cancer follow-up. While liver metastases can occur in breast cancer, LFT monitoring is usually reserved for patients on certain medications or with specific clinical indications.

 

Option C. Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months: While tumor markers like CA 15-3 and CA 27.29 can be useful in some cases for monitoring breast cancer, they are not the primary means of follow-up and are not recommended for routine use as they can have limitations in sensitivity and specificity.

 

Option D. Yearly bone scans: Yearly bone scans are not part of routine breast cancer follow-up unless there is clinical suspicion of bone metastases. Performing bone scans annually would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation and costs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of routine physical examination once in 3 months for a year and annual mammogram.

 

Mammography is the only imaging modality required for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. Tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scan currently have no role in follow-up.

 

Guidelines for follow-up:

 

Physical examination:

 

  • For the first 2 years: once every 3 to 6 months
  • For 3-5 years: once every 6 to 12 months
  • After 5 years: Annually

 

Mammography:

 

  • Initially, 6 months after surgery
  • Thereafter, annually.

choices.text: The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck Stabilization
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X ray
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support
The doctor should order a cervical X ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself

questions.text: A victim of a road traffic accident presented with paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization

 

The given clinical situation is suggestive of a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.

 

This option is correct because the patient is experiencing paralysis of both upper and lower limbs, which is indicative of a potential cervical spine injury. In such cases, it is crucial not to move the patient until the cervical spine is stabilized to prevent any further damage. Using a portable X-ray machine can help assess the cervical spine without the need to move the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X-rays: The patient's cervical spine must be stabilized before any radiographic evaluation is performed.

 

Option C. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X-ray AP and lateral views without any cervical support: This option is not advisable because taking X-rays without cervical support can potentially worsen the patient's condition if there is a cervical spine injury. The patient's neck should be stabilized before any imaging is done.

 

Option D. The doctor should order a cervical X-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself: This option is not recommended because moving the patient without proper cervical spine stabilization can lead to further injury. The priority should be to immobilize the cervical spine and use imaging techniques that do not require moving the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management in a trauma patient with suspected cervical fracture consists of:

 

  1. The immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases is spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board
  2. It is followed by eliciting extremity movement to grossly assess spinal cord function. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicated an associated fracture.

 

Imaging is done by X-ray or CT with portable X-ray machines being preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but they cannot be used to visualize the cervicothoracic junction.

questions.text: Locally advanced breast cancer can be defined as all except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor more than 4 cm

 

While a tumor size larger than 4 cm is indicative of a relatively large tumor, it alone does not define locally advanced breast cancer. Locally advanced breast cancer typically involves not only tumor size but also the extent of its spread to nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inflammatory breast cancer: Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive subtype of breast cancer characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth in the breast. It is considered an advanced stage of breast cancer.

 

Option C. Chest wall involvement: Locally advanced breast cancer is often defined by its involvement of the chest wall. This means that the cancer has spread beyond the breast tissue and may affect the underlying muscles and structures of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Skin involvement: Skin involvement, such as changes in the appearance of the skin over the breast like peau’d orange or ulceration, can be a feature of locally advanced breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor more than 5 cm, not 4 is classified as LABC.

 

Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes: (Mnemonic – CUBE N2)

 

C - Chest wall invasion

 

U - Ulceration of skin

 

B - Both (chest wall invasion and ulceration of skin)

 

E - E(I)nflammatory carcinoma

 

N2 - fixed axillary lymph nodes

choices.text: Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts.
It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions.
The most dangerous complication is sepsis.
The most common indication is the ischemia

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about intestinal transplantation: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts

 

This statement is incorrect. While multi-visceral transplantation, which includes the intestine along with other abdominal organs like the liver and pancreas, can occur, it is not the most common type of intestinal transplantation. Isolated intestinal transplantation, where only the intestine is transplanted, is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions: This statement is correct. Intestinal transplantation is not as widely performed as other organ transplants like kidney or liver transplantation because the intestine is known to trigger vigorous rejection reactions.

 

Option C. The most dangerous complication is sepsis: This statement is correct. Sepsis is indeed a significant and life-threatening complication associated with intestinal transplantation. The immunosuppressive medications used to prevent rejection can increase the risk of infections, including sepsis.

 

Option D. The most common indication is ischemia. (Correct): Ischemia is one of the common indications for intestinal transplantation. It is often used when patients have suffered from ischemic bowel disease and other treatments have been ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multi-visceral grafts are rarely used in intestinal transplantation. The most common intestinal graft is small bowel graft, with or without the colon or a combined liver and small bowel graft.

 

All the other statements are correct.

 

Small bowel transplantation is the final treatment option when the outcome of reconstruction and lengthening procedures are unsatisfactory.

 

The small bowel transplant is highly immunogenic as it contains a large amount of gut-associated lymphoid tissue, donor dendritic cells, and macrophages. Acute rejection has been reported in 56-75% of patients, with small bowel transplant limiting the overall survival to only one-third of recipients.
